economic_context.details: Multiple disputes over payment: witness 6 refused to pay money owed to her husband; witness 11 refused to pay her share for keeping animals; witness 14 (lieutenant of maire) quarrelled with her when collecting debts. Husband was herdsman. Accused described as 'very poor' - husband had only one arm. Disputes often over animal damage to fields.

material_culture.context: Claudatte seen coming out of house with a bucket
unusually large grey cat that followed her; died after eating bad egg
offered to be allowed to stay at home instead of going to confrontation
stepson was making cloth for her; she held it back when payment dispute arose
son-in-law coming back from baker with loaf which was 'fort rude et noir'
bad egg which she cooked with cream for her son; cat ate it and died
cooked egg with cream for her son

spatial_references.context: Primary location of trial; residence of accused
Home of Jean Gregoire Mathis who accused her of making hail
Where Claudatte and husband were guarding lesser animals 5 years earlier
Home of hangman who examined bewitched ox
Her father was procureur for abbess of Remiremont
Multiple incidents of animals straying into her grain fields
Wood rented by witness where pigs did damage

prior_legal_disputes.description: Had reparation from brother-in-law Claudel le Maimbourg for calling her witch and throwing her to the ground
Nicolas Cointzelin called her witch but did not obtain reparation because he was away for at least 6 weeks

legal_context.redress_outcome: Obtained reparation from brother-in-law for being called witch; could not obtain it from Nicolas Cointzelin who was away
legal_context.imprisonment_conditions: Possibly imprisoned from November 1609 to April 1610 (text unclear)

change_de_nancy.modification_details: Approved only question ordinaire; rejected question extraordinaire requested by Substitut

hearsay_chains.content: Incident of Claudatte calling for devil during quarrel with husband

reproaches_to_witnesses.objection: Said she herself had told him to keep cloth until they could pay him
Explained that she told son-in-law the rough black loaf would not be good for him since he was ill, and he should feed himself properly
Said Dieudonné Jean Nicole had been hostile to her for 3 years without cause; her husband had only one arm and was very poor, so they had wanted to take action against him
Agreed he had called her witch, but said there had been no witnesses

third_parties.name: Jean Gregoire Mathis
third_parties.context: From Bertrimoutier; claimed to have seen her making hail and cooking 'oisillons' in daytime; she had been confronted with him

third_parties.name: Claudel le Maimbourg
third_parties.context: Called her witch; threw her to the ground; she obtained reparation from him

third_parties.name: Nicolas Cointzelin
third_parties.context: Called her witch; was away for at least 6 weeks so she could not obtain reparation

third_parties.name: wife of Nicolas Cointzelin
third_parties.context: Witness 5 spoke to her about Claudatte offering silver to avoid confrontation

third_parties.name: Mengel Louys
third_parties.context: Told witness 9 about incident of Claudatte calling for devil; possibly related to witness 8 (Collatte veuve Demenge Louys)

third_parties.name: hangman of St Dié
third_parties.context: Cut up bewitched ox and found small marks like barleycorns inside it; said it was bewitched 'de la plus parfaicte sorcelerie que se puisse trouver'

third_parties.name: son of Claudatte
third_parties.context: Only child; still living; egg cooked for him with cream

third_parties.name: son-in-law of Jean l'Hoste
third_parties.context: Was making cloth for Claudatte; was already ill when she met him; told him illness would be for all his life; died 3 or 4 weeks later

third_parties.name: wife of Jean l'Hoste
third_parties.context: Claudatte told her she should have mentioned suspicion to her alone, not to everyone

third_parties.name: father of Demenge Michiel le jeune
third_parties.context: Found pigs doing damage in wood he rented

third_parties.name: grandson of father of Demenge Michiel le jeune
third_parties.context: Claudatte threatened to have her reason from him in his cradle if she could not get it from his grandfather; thanks to God no harm came to child

third_parties.name: mother of Claude Peterman
third_parties.context: Her cows got into Claudatte's field; two cows fell ill

third_parties.name: abbess of Remiremont
third_parties.context: Claudatte's father Jean Badouin had been procureur for abbess of Remiremont

extraction_metadata.notes: Trial of Claudatte, wife of Jean Claudel le Maimbourg, from Raves. Accused primarily based on pattern of animal deaths following quarrels over straying animals and field damage. Notable for: 1) survived torture without confessing; 2) Change de Nancy limited torture to ordinaire only; 3) ultimately released; 4) may have been imprisoned for approximately 5 months after sentence; 5) had previously obtained legal reparation for being called witch; 6) described as very poor, husband had only one arm; 7) multiple witnesses testified to same pattern of quarrel-threat-harm. Witnesses 2 and 3 are father and son, corroborating same ox death incident. Witness 4 and witness 12 names are missing in source document.
